awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Noise and Stability Analysis in Monolithic Mode-Locked Lasers
awd_abstract_narration:
Pulsed lasers have played a central role in a large number of applications ranging from fundamental scientific studies to industry. In the coming decades, pulsed lasers "in the form of optical frequency combs" will help unravel current mysteries in science, such as dark energy or the potential time-dependence of fundamental constants. But many of these experiments are now approaching the limits of existing tools. Continued progress in these fields will require new approaches. This project will deliver a new framework for understanding the quantum and classical noise limitations in pulsed laser sources and demonstrate novel interdisciplinary approaches towards creating a new kind of pulsed laser that will serve as the next generation of optical precision tools.

This project will lead to robust pulsed lasers with record-low noise performance, which will have a strong impact on science and technology. In astronomy, they will aid programs such as the dark energy search through the calibration of astronomical telescopes. In basic physics, they will serve as new precision tools for atomic and molecular spectroscopy. The project will also serve the scientific community by training and mentoring graduate and undergraduate students, and broadening the participation of underrepresented groups through an extensive set of outreach activities and diverse recruitment efforts. Finally, impact on society will occur notably through novel medical diagnostics, environmental sensing, and high-speed optical telecommunication systems.

por.por_cntn:
This award enabled the creation of a theoretical framework, which accurately predicts the noise behavior of mode-locked lasers. Such lasers produce pulses that are much shorter in length than the laser resonator itself. Typical pulse durations considered here range from a few femtoseconds to hundreds of picoseconds. The framework is aimed at lasers with intended uses in precision optical metrology, such as in AMO physics, but also for precision dimensional metrology and photonic microwave systems. Dimensional metrology is particularly important for industrial settings, such as tooling and chip manufacturing, while photonic microwave technology find widespread use in R&D and national defense. The noise model created under this award has no free parameters and has been verified experimentally at the level, where vacuum fluctuations (a minute quantum effect) limit the noise behavior of the laser. The agreement was always within the measurement limit over a dynamic range covering more than 20-decades in noise power. To cover such a large dynamic range, a new optical timing measurement technique was developed, reaching a timing resolution at the yoctosecond per root Hertz level. This is to the best of our knowledge the highest timing resolution ever demonstrated experimentally for optical signals.

With this noise model, a new type of mode-locked lasers was created. These lasers are fully monolithic, that means, they have no adjustable degrees of freedom, and the laser light in the cavity is confined inside a rigid and transparent medium (CaF2 in this first realization). These lasers form a new class of mode-locked lasers (besides the existing mode-locked free-space, fiber and diode lasers), and offer ultra-low quantum-limited phase noise. Indeed, at short timescales, the intrinsic noise in these lasers is typically much lower than the best, fully phase stabilized fiber-lasers. It is this ultra-low intrinsic phase noise that has enabled the creation of frequency combs with unprecedented stabilities at short timescales (demonstrated out-of-loop instability of 1 part in 10-19 at 1 second integration time).

One of the perhaps technologically most important demonstrations from this award was the generation of the lowest phase noise photonic microwaves from a free-running laser to date. Such ultra-low phase noise microwave signals have significant uses in science (e.g. in astronomy), defense (e.g. position, navigation and timing, radar and sensing), and in industrial settings (precision instrumentation, e.g. for 5G and beyond). Indeed, the phase noise produced by these lasers is so low, that novel techniques had to be developed to fully characterize the performance of these signals. For this, we created an electro-optic sampling technique, that allows the direct comparison between these microwaves, and an ultra-stable optical frequency comb. This setup reached timing resolutions in the microwave domain at the zepto-second per root hertz level. Overall, work performed under this award has been disseminated through more than a dozen peer reviewed journal articles, two physics colloquia, 14 invited talks and more than two dozen contributed papers at peer-reviewed international conferences.

Besides the scientific achievements, this award also partially supported educational and outreach efforts involving K12 students, ~10 college undergrad and 6 graduate students from CU Boulder and an additional 4 visiting graduate students from outside of Colorado. This research was also key to several follow-up collaborations with industry through which students learned more about the business side of R&D.

On the technology side, the perhaps most noteworthy piece of technology that came from this grant is the aforementioned compact, ultra-low noise monolithic mode-locked laser (MMLL). These lasers have recently been patented. As part of our tech-transfer efforts, we worked on a few demonstrations (with funding from industry outside of this grant) to showcase the capabilities of these sources for commercial and defense-related applications. We continue to work on tech-transfer to industry and DoD. Key interests are: low phase-noise frequency combs, microwave generation and portable optical atomic & molecular clocks for position, navigation and timing (PNT)-related uses.
